ldsep 2.2.0

Naive approach to estimate LD using posterior moments.

Source: R/fast.R
ldfast_naive.Rd

Here, we just use posterior means as a proxy for the genotypes, and calculate these LD estimates as if the genotypes were known. This is not a good way to do things if there is any genotype uncertainty (which is almost always the case in polyploids).

ldfast_naive(gp, type = c("r", "r2", "z", "D", "Dprime"))

Arguments

gp

A three-way array with dimensions SNPs by individuals by dosage. That is, gp[i, j, k] is the posterior probability of dosage k-1 for individual j at SNP i.

type

What LD measure should we estimate?

"r"

The Pearson correlation.

"r2"

The squared Pearson correlation.

"z"

The Fisher-z transformed Pearson correlation.

"D"

The LD coefficient.

"Dprime"

The standardized LD coefficient.

Note that these are all composite measures of LD (see the description in ldest()).

Value

A list with the following elements.

ldmat

The bias-corrected LD matrix.

Author

David Gerard

Examples

data("glike")
gp <- gl_to_gp(gl = glike, prior_mat = "estimate_pnorm")
ldfast_naive(gp = gp)
#> $ldmat
